As a Christian Private school, we continue to make plans to meet in person employing safety measures to social distance and maintain our small class ratio of 6:1

Last week we shared an interview discussing how people with dyslexia use a different side of their brain to read. That interview references a study performed by Dr. Sally Shaywitz at Yale University.
In the time since, Dr. Shaywitz started the Yale Institute for Dyslexia with her husband and wrote a book, Overcoming Dyslexia. She makes a point in her book that due to the opposite side brain use, there is a need for more processing time to help reading comprehension. This is the basis for a significant portion of our outside the box learning techniques.
You can learn more about Dr. Shaywitz and her work at dyslexia.yale.edu.

shared_text:
Bible Study Fellowship - Southlake Evening Women
May 9 at 6:48 AM ·

This might be the most amazing data picture you see in a lifetime! It shows the 63,779 cross-references in the Bible. The white bars along the bottom represent each Bible chapter, Gen. 1 - Rev. 22. The line’s color shows the reference’s distance from the other. A cross reference is a scripture that references another scripture. Had the Bible been written by one person or at one time this would still be amazing; however, the Bible was written by 40 authors over the span of 1500 years on 3 different continents.
The Bible is complex, diverse, and intricate, and yet it has one unified message: God lovingly is redeeming all who believe!

Is your child diagnosed with a learning disability? Are they receiving the time and resources they need to learn differently from their school?

If not, it’s time to consider an alternative. Even with coronavirus pushing us to digital education for the short term, we at Inspire approach education differently.
Our small teacher to student ratio allows for a more personalized approach, while a focus on students with learning disabilities means every teacher understands what your son or daughter is going through. Instead of being an exception, they get to join a community of people (students and teachers) similar to themselves with teaching methods designed specifically for them.

Today is the day to learn more about Inspire Academy and give your son or daughter the resources they deserve.

OUR ENEMIES
These who are not "flesh-and-blood enemies" are demons over whom the devil has control. They are not mere fantasies—they are very real. We face a powerful army whose goal is to defeat Christ's church. When we believe in Christ, these beings become our enemies, and they try every device to turn us away from him and back to sin. The great unknown.
-
With so much misunderstood about learning disabilities, we decided it would be a great time to for a few little known facts!
-
There are no medical tests for LDs, and no medication that cures them.
LDs are not caused by the environment children are raised in, but do run in the family. Learning disabilities do not equate to low intelligence. In fact, by the parameters set around the term “learning disability,” people with them have average or above average intelligence.
-
People (that’s right, kids with LDs grow into adults with LDs) with learning disabilities aren’t lazy, dumb, or a product of their environment. They need a welcoming environment that helps them access the best of their abilities, just like everyone else.

10 things about dyslexia every teacher needs to know
by Nickola Wolf Nelson
developer of the TILLS test

1. Dyslexia is a language-based learning disability.

It’s not a vision problem. It’s not about intelligence. It certainly isn’t about laziness. It affects the way the brain processes written and spoken language.

Nelson says people with dyslexia have trouble mapping letters onto sounds and vice versa.

Students with dyslexia usually have a hard time reading, but they can also struggle with spelling, writing and even pronouncing words.
